The kinetics of methanol to formaldehyde oxidation over iron molybdates catalysts has been studied. Data were obtained in integral reactor conditions and the rates of the products formation were computed by differentiation of experimental data yield versus contact time. Catalytic tests were performed over stoichiometric (Mo/Fe=1.5 at. ratio) and Mo rich (Mo/Fe=3 at. ratio) catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and sol-gel like techniques. The Mo/Fe atomic ratio of the catalysts seems to have a null effect on the methanol to formaldehyde kinetics what is coherent with the attribution of the active phase to the Fe2(MoO4)3, the main phase of the tested catalysts. A direct correlation between the CO formation and the Mo/Fe atomic ratio was not inferred mainly due to the different degrees of reduction of the tested catalysts (Fe2+/Fe3+), but the Mo/Fe ratio plays an important role on the consecutive oxidation of formaldehyde to CO thus controlling catalyst selectivity. Y i yield of the i product. y MeOH o molar faction of methanol in the reactor feed. y O 2 o molar fraction of oxygen in the reactor feed. ε i stoichiometric coefficient. 1 Introduction People benefit from products that contain formaldehyde every day. Formaldehyde, a small and versatile molecule (HCHO) has several applications in resins, fibers, solvents, preservatives, plasticizers, drying agents, coatings, among others with a global market which is expected to reach US$ 15 Bn by 2031 [1]. The price for formaldehyde is closely coupled with the price for methanol. In fact, methanol is the raw material used in industry to produce formaldehyde. The commercial production of formaldehyde was first started in Germany in the 1880 s but the development of a methanol synthesis route in the 1920 s gave the spur to the development of large-scale manufacture. Today there are two main production routes: oxidation-dehydrogenation using a silver catalyst involving either the complete or incomplete conversion of methanol; and the direct oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde using oxides type catalysts. Hybrid processes are also used in industry [2]. Iron molybdates are industrial catalysts for selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde [2]. Since the pioneer work of Adkins et al. [3] in 1931, a large number of papers and patents has been published and the catalytic systems his relatively well characterized [2]. Industrial iron molybdate catalysts present large Mo excess and but its role remains doubtful [4–7]. Pure MoO3 presents high selectivity towards formaldehyde, but the activity is low. Contrarily the Fe2O3 shows high activity but low formaldehyde selectivity. Over hematite methanol is totally oxidized to CO. Actually Mo-Fe mixed oxides present high catalytic performances for selective oxidation of methanol and it is believed by the majority of researchers that a Mo excess is needed to avoid the formation of unselective iron rich phases during the redox process. In fact, Mo is lost by volatilization during reaction[8]. Recently, Kong et al. [9] reported a green synthesis method of MoFeO catalyst using a mechanochemical route, emphasizing an improved formaldehyde selectivity for mixed oxide samples with higher content of Fe2(MoO4)3 crystalline phase. The authors also reported a lower formaldehyde selectivity for catalyst with segregated plates of MoO3 and granules of Fe2(MoO4)3. A cooperative effect between the Mo excess (MoO3) and the molybdate phase was claimed by Dias et al. [10]. As reported before, the authors found improved formaldehyde selectivity for Mo rich catalysts. Data from Ruan et al. [11] corroborate the fact that Fe2(MoO4)3 phase plays a crucial for the high selectivity towards formaldehyde. Chowdhry et al. [12] reported that Fe-Mo mixed oxides catalysts are more active than pure MoO3 but the selectivity towards formaldehyde and the kinetics is similar for both materials. House et al. [13] studied the methanol oxidation over MoO3 and hematite using pulse reactor. They confirmed the high selectivity of MoO3 toward formaldehyde and high activity of hematite but low selectivity. The researchers attributed the different catalytic behaviors observed to the stronger oxygen biding energy of hematite. It is generally accepted that methanol to formaldehyde oxidation, over iron molybdate catalysts, proceeds via a Mars van Krevelen redox mechanisms [2]. Recently Bowker confirmed a Mars-van Krevelen reaction mechanism in which the active species are surface lattice oxygens. The author also underlined the crucial role of high oxidation state (VI) surface Mo species on the catalyst selectivity [14]. According to Pernicone [15] such mechanism can by schematized by: CH3OH+□+O2-→(CH3O-□)-+OH- (CH3O-□)-+ O2-→(CH2O-□)2-+OH- 2 O H − D ⇄ H 2 O + O 2 − + ̈ (CH2O-□)2-→HCHO+□2- 1/2 O2 +□2-→ O2- Where □ is an anionic vacancy and O2- is lattice oxygen. The same author reported that Mo6+ provides adsorption sites for methanol forming an alcoholate complex. Allisson and Goddard III [16] also reported a similar reaction intermediate involving a dual dioxo Mo site: Image 1 . Analogous methanol adsorption sites were described by Machiels et al. [17] proposed the methanol adsorption site involving two adjacent molybdenums: Image 2 . Taking into account the behavior of some trivalent (Al, Cr) metal molybdates, Pernicone [18] emphasized that the role of Fe is to increase the number of methanol adsorption sites existing in stationary conditions by making the dehydroxylation of the catalyst surface easier. The methanol to formaldehyde oxidation produces water. Typically, authors report a competitive dissociative adsorption of water and methanol on molybdenum sites. Thus, water is referred to have an inhibition effect on the methanol oxidation reaction. Certain researchers reported that water is responsible for the high selectivity towards formaldehyde since avoid its readsorption and consecutive reactions [2]. Deshmukh et al. [19] proposed for the same reaction a Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetics assuming two different metal oxide sites, one containing adsorbed oxygenates and the other containing lattice oxygen. For this mechanism water also has an inhibition effect by competitive adsorption. Regarding the above features for the methanol oxidation reaction mechanism researchers proposed several kinetics laws ( Table 1). For the proposed laws the methanol reaction order varies in the range 1–0.5 and the order relative to oxygen is usually lower than 0.5 been zero when oxygen is in excess. The activation energy is around 20 kcal/mol at 275 °C [2]. Kinetics data strongly depends on the reaction conditions used. In spite of the high selectivity of the iron molybdates catalysts for methanol to formaldehyde reaction other products are also formed depending on the catalyst type and reaction conditions. The reactions occurring during methanol oxidation over Mo-Fe-O catalysts can be divided in two main types [20]: i. Oxidation reactions, which need oxygen ii. Dehydration reactions, which do not need oxygen Generally, the reaction products can be accounted for by the reactions [2]: (r1) C H 3 OH + 1 2 O 2 → HCHO + H 2 O (r2) C H 3 OH + C H 3 OH → C H 3 OC H 3 + H 2 O (r3) C H 3 OH + HCHO + 1 2 O 2 → HCOOC H 3 + H 2 O (r4) 2 C H 3 OH + HCHO → C H 2 OC H 3 2 + H 2 O (r5) HCHO + 1 / 2 O 2 → CO + H 2 O The selectivity towards formaldehyde increases raising the methanol conversion since for the formation of DME, MF and DMM unreacted methanol must be available in the reaction medium [2]. Gribovskii et al. [21] reported, using a complex microchannel reactor, high formaldehyde selectivities (near 100%) even for methanol conversion lower than 30%. Formic acid is rarely observed in the reactor outlet mainly due to its instability in reaction conditions. Carbon monoxide is the main by product in industry. Despite the industrial relevance of this secondary reaction, due to its negative effect, only few researchers studied their kinetics. The large variety of kinetics laws ( Table 2), obtained by a few researchers, can be due to the different reaction conditions employed. In fact, most of the researchers consider that CO is only formed by oxidation of formaldehyde, but any carbon compound can be converted to CO. The various pathways for CO formation depend on the reaction conditions. Although the large volume of research work published during more than 50 years several items remain unclear for the above-mentioned catalytic system. In order to contribute to the knowledge in this research field the next sections present the results and discussion of a kinetics study for methanol to formaldehyde oxidation. The catalytic data were obtained with an integral reactor using catalysts with different Mo/Fe atomic ratios prepared by coprecipitation and sol-gel like route. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts Stoichiometric (Mo/Fe=1.5 at. ratio) and molybdenum rich (Mo/Fe=3 at. ratio) catalysts have been prepared by coprecipitation [22] and sol-gel like [23,24] techniques. Briefly the coprecipitated samples were prepared from aqueous solutions of Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24. All the reagents were p.a. grade. In order to avoid gel formation during coprecipitation low concentration solutions have been used. The iron nitrate solution was slowly added to the ammonium heptamolybdate solution under vigorous stirring. Before filtration, precipitates remained in contact with mother-liquors for 3 h at boiling temperature. Additionally, samples with the same Mo/Fe atomic ratios (1.5 and 3) were prepared by a sol-gel like technique using propionic acid as chelating agent. Details on the preparation method are given elsewhere [23,24]. For both preparation techniques the powder materials obtained by crushing in a pyrex mortar were dried (overnight at 120 °C) and then calcined under slow flow of dried air at 475 °C during 10 h. An industrial Mo rich catalyst (Mo/Fe=3 at. ratio), provided by a local formaldehyde industry was used as standard for the catalytic behavior. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts For fresh catalysts the elemental composition, near surface, was assessed by SEM-EDS using a JEOL JSM 840 equipment with a Delta Kevex energy dispersive X-ray analyser. The BET surface areas were measured with a Perkin-Elmer Shell 212 C sorptometer by N2 physisorption. The bulk elemental compositions were determined by induced coupled plasma (ICP). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a D5000 Siemens diffractometer with a primary beam quartz monochromator (Co Kα1 =1.78897 Å) at 40 kV and 25 mA. The bulk compositions of iron phases, for fresh and post reaction catalysts samples were studied by transmission Mössbauer spectroscopy at room temperature with a time mode spectrometer, a constant acceleration drive and a 57Co in a Rh matrix source. The isomer shifts (δ) were given with respect to α-Fe at room temperature and calculated as the quadrupole splittings (Δ) and the line widths (W) with a precision of 0.02 mm s−1. Details on spectral parameters calculations are given elsewhere [22]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate the chemical analysis and reduction state of the surface of the fresh catalysts. The analyses were performed with a VG ESCA 3 apparatus. The kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron was given by E Kin= 1486.6 − E Bcor, where 1486.6 eV is the energy of the incident radiation (Al Kα) and E Bcor the corrected binding energy of the electron. The binding energy of the electron, corrected from charge effects, was calibrated with respect to the signal for adventitious carbon (binding energy: 284.8 eV). 2.3 Catalytic tests Methanol oxidation was carried out in a conventional continuous flow apparatus at atmospheric pressure. Catalytic behavior was studied in steady state conditions. Feed mixtures (6%, v/v) were prepared by injecting methanol into the air flow with a precise Gilson 302 pump. The catalysts were diluted with inert SiC (1:4, w/w) to avoid adverse thermal effects and charged into a tubular pyrex reactor with a thermocouple in a coaxial centered thermowell. Catalyst particles of diameter dp < 125 µm (115 mesh sieve) were used in order to minimize the effects of internal diffusion limitations on the mass and heat transfer. The reactor outlet was kept at 130 °C, to prevent condensation of liquid products and formaldehyde polymerization, and was connected to a Shimadzu GC-8A gas chromatograph with thermal conductivity detector. Two in-parallel columns, one at room temperature (molecular sieve 13X) for N2, O2, and CO and the other in the oven of the chromatograph (Porapak T) at 443 K for air, CO2, HCHO, CH3OCH3 (DME), H2O, CH3OH (MeOH), HCOOCH3 (MF) and CH2(OCH3)2 (DMM), performed the separation of the reactor effluents. Formic acid was never detected. The carbon balance was evaluated for each catalytic test and the data were rejected if the error was higher than 5%. 3 Results and discussion Results in Table 3 show, as reported before [25], that sol-gel like route allows to obtain materials with larger surface area than those obtained by coprecipitation. Also, the Mo rich samples present a larger surface area than the stoichiometric sample. The elemental compositions in Table 3 show that catalysts prepared by sol-gel technique presented lower Mo/Fe ratio than the previewed considering the same ratio in the precursor’s solutions. Since the combustion of carbon precursors (carbon was added as propionic acid) is highly exothermic, during calcination step occurs Mo species loss by sublimation/volatilization. All the prepared catalyst displayed a near surface (EDS) Mo/Fe ratio higher than the bulk value (ICP) whereas XPS data showed surface Mo/Fe ratios always higher than the stoichiometric value and around 2. The Fe2+/Fe3+ ratios obtained by XPS showed that fresh catalysts are partially reduced even before reaction. The sample prepared by sol-gel presented higher degree of surface reduction than the coprecipitated samples. This result for sol-gel samples can be explained considering that some iron species are reduced during carbon species oxidation that occurs during calcination. Moreover, for coprecipitation technique both samples displayed similar degrees of reduction. The presence of reduced iron species was confirmed by Mössbauer spectroscopy. The data in Table 3 show measurable amounts of reduced phases for sol-gel samples and confirm the fact that sol-gel technique allows to higher reduction state than coprecipitation technique. The sol-gel sample with lower Mo/Fe ratio presents iron oxide what is consistent with its substoichiometric Mo/Fe ratio (Mo/Fe= 1.2 at. ratio by ICP). Despite the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratios no reduced iron molybdate or iron phases have been observed by XRD (Table 3). In fact, the detection level of XRD is reported to be around 7% (w/w) thus the reduced iron molybdate phase and the iron oxide observed by Mössbauer remain undetected by XRD. The catalysts prepared by both techniques displayed analogous XRD characteristics but with low crystallinity for sol-gel samples. The stoichiometric sample, prepared by coprecipitation, presented XRD lines ascribable to Fe2(MoO4)3. The main XRD lines of the Mo-rich samples were attributable to the Fe2(MoO4)3.xMoO3 and MoO3 phases [22]. 3.1 Catalytic activity Due to the high activity of tested catalyst, conversion was always higher than 10%. Thus, integral reactor was considered. The kinetics data were obtained for reaction mixtures containing 6% of methanol in air, reaction temperatures in the range 275–375 °C and contact times in the range 5–40 gcat.h/molCH3OH. Only appreciable amounts of formaldehyde and CO were detected for all the prepared catalysts ( Fig. 1A, Fig. 1B and Fig. 1C). For stoichiometric samples, coprecipitated and sol-gel like, measurable amounts of DME were also detected in the reactor outlet. The formation of dimethyl ether is more probable when large amounts of methanol are available on the catalyst surface (low methanol conversion) and the oxygen is scarce. The catalytic tests were performed with a large excess of oxygen and with high methanol conversion (low methanol availability) what explains the low selectivities towards dimethyl ether observed (Fig. 1B). The products yields (Yi) were plotted (Figs. 1A, 1B &1 C) versus contact time (τ j ) for each studied reaction temperature (j). The results in Fig. 1A show, as expected, that the formaldehyde yield increase raising the contact time and the reaction temperature, except for high conversion levels (high contact time) when the consecutive oxidation of formaldehyde becomes significant [22]. The rates of products formation (ri j , i-product, j-temperature) can be computed by differentiation of the fitted curves (f i (τ j )) to products yields (Y ij ) experimental data (Eq.1): (1) r ij = ∂ f i ( τ ) ∂ τ j For formaldehyde yield the experimental data (Fig. 1A) several curves (f i (τ j )) have being tested and the chosen, on basis of the squared correlation coefficient, was (Eq.2): (2) Y HCHO = A . τ + B . τ 1.2 For the prepared catalysts the fitted parameters A and B as well as the squared correlation coefficients are resumed in Tables 4 and 5. The rates of formaldehyde formation were computed by differentiation of the above curve. For each formaldehyde rate value, the composition of the reaction mixture was computed considering the following set of reaction that account for the products observed in the reactor outlet. Thus, the partial pressures of methanol, oxygen and water were computed by (Eq.3 and eq. 4): (3) P MeOH = P T . Y MeOH o ( 1 X ) (4) P H 2 O = P T . Y MeOH o . ( Y 1 + 1 2 Y 2 + Y 3 + 1 3 Y 4 + 2 Y 5 ) For other products the partial pressure was computed using (Eq.5): (5) P i = P T . Y MeOH o . Y i . 1 ε i Where ε i is the stoichiometric coefficient. Different kinetics laws have been proposed by several authors for the methanol to formaldehyde oxidation reaction (Table 1). The available data, relatively scarce, discourages the fitting of complex kinetics laws with several parameters. Thus, a power law, as proposed by Holstein and Machiels [26], was adopted (Eq.6): (6) r HCHO = k C MeOH m C O 2 n C H 2 O l This kinetics law includes the water inhibition effect. As underlined by the authors the true value of the reaction rate is only obtained when the inhibition effects accounted for. In fact, several authors reported that water, a reaction product, adsorb competitively with the methanol in the same active site [20,27] thus hindering the reaction. Some of them also claimed that this effect is responsible for the high selectivity towards formaldehyde exhibited by iron molybdates catalysts [26]. The catalytic tests were always performed with a large oxygen excess ( y o 2 0 ≈ 19 % ) thus its concentration was considered constant. The kinetics law parameters were computed using the SOLVER routine of EXCEL software, imposing k > 0 and m , − 1 ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] . The optimum values were obtained minimizing the objective function FO (Eq.7): (7) FO = ∑ i r exp − r comp r exp 2 where r exp is the observed reaction rate and r comp is the computed value. Experimental data and fitted kinetics laws are in Fig. 2. For all the tested catalysts optimum fittings were obtained for m= 1 and l= −1 evidencing the strong inhibition effect of water. The Arrhenius plots for computed kinetics constants (k) are in Fig. 3 Nonetheless for stoichiometric samples and Mo rich prepared by sol-gel technique the Arrhenius are the same within the error margin. The activation energy around 22 Kcal/mol agrees with previously published results [16]. Thus, it can be concluded that the Mo/Fe atomic ratio of the catalyst is irrelevant for the kinetics of the methanol to formaldehyde oxidation. This result agrees with the attribution of the active phase to the Fe2(MoO4)3 [6]. The Mo excess is only a spectator phase [15]. For the Mo rich sample prepared by coprecipitation, the Arrhenius parameters are different what can be ascribable to the slightly different reaction conditions. In fact, this sample was tested for higher reaction temperatures what can be responsible for a different slow step and by different activation energy. The main byproduct in the tested conditions was carbon monoxide. In an analogous manner the rate of CO production was computed by differentiation of the fitted curves to experimental data CO yields versus contact time. As previously reported [28] experimental rates of CO formation fitted with power kinetics law(Eq.8): (8) r CO = k ′ C MeOH m 1 C O 2 n 1 C H 2 O l 1 The kinetics parameters (k′,m1,n1,l1) were computed as above described for the formaldehyde reaction rate. Experimental data and fitted kinetics laws are in Fig. 4. The best fitting was obtained for m1 = 0.5, n1 = −1 and l1 = −1. For the Mo/Fe= 3 coprecipitated catalyst the inhibitor effect of water is minor (l1 =0). Astonishingly, the rate of CO production is proportional to methanol concentration instead of the expected formaldehyde concentration. This result pointed out that, in tested condition, the direct overoxidation of methanol was not negligible. CO can, in theory, be simultaneously formed by oxidation of any of the reaction products. As expected, the water inhibits the CO formation thus improving the catalyst selectivity. Contrary to the observed for the rate of formaldehyde formation the CO depends on the Mo/Fe ratio of the catalyst and certainly on its Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio. Arrhenius plots in Fig. 5 show different activation energy for each tested catalyst but sol-gel catalysts display similar value and higher than coprecipitated ones what explains observed high formaldehyde selectivity, for high reaction temperature, for these catalysts. The Mo/Fe atomic ratio seems to have an important role in the catalyst selectivity since the kinetics of the main byproduct (CO) depend on its value. This result is in line with the high selectivity towards formaldehyde (around 100%) obtained when methanol is oxidized over pure MoO3. 4 Conclusions Iron molybdate catalysts are well established catalytic systems for selective oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde, an important building block for more complex products such as rubber. The active phase of the catalysts is ascribed to the stoichiometric mixed oxide (Fe2(MoO4)3) but industrial catalysts present a high molybdenum excess, usually with Mo/Fe atomic ratios higher than 3. Recently researchers claimed a synergy effect between the MoO3 and the Fe2(MoO4)3 what apparently opposes the former spectator role attributed to the MoO3 excess. In order to contribute to clarify the role of the Mo excess on the catalytic performances of iron molybdates catalysts stoichiometric and Mo rich samples were prepared by coprecipitation and sol-gel like techniques. Data from characterization techniques revealed that sol-gel technique allows catalysts with higher surface areas but with higher surface reduction. For both preparation techniques samples showed Mo surface enrichment but always with Fe2(MoO4)3 as the main bulk component. Kinetics studies performed in integral conditions revealed that the Mo excess has an almost null effect on the formaldehyde production rate. Data computed by differentiation of experimental data of formaldehyde yield versus contact time fitted well to kinetics power law with a first order methanol dependence showing a strong water inhibition effect due to the recognized competitive adsorption between water and methanol in the same active sites. The activation energy computed based on the Arrhenius plot was 22 kcal/mol what agrees with previously published values by other authors. Kinetics analysis of CO production, computed as above referred by differentiation of yield versus contact time curves, showed a power kinetics law dependent of the methanol concentration (reaction order 0.5), hindered by formaldehyde and water. Methanol dependence seems to indicate that CO is produced by other overoxidation processes than that of formaldehyde. Apparently, any molecule containing carbon, in reaction medium can be converted into CO. This would explain the observed lack of usual reaction products such as dimethyl ether, methyl formate and dimethoxymethane in the reactor effluent. Contrary to the null effect observed for the formaldehyde formation rate, the Mo/Fe ratio seems to affect the CO formation. All the tested catalyst presented different Arrhenius plots for the CO formation kinetic constant. Additionally, the samples prepared by sol-gel method presented higher activation energy what explains their highest formaldehyde selectivity. The higher activation energy would be related to their higher surface reduction. CRediT authorship contribution statement A.P. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of methanol to formaldehyde oxidation over iron molybdates catalysts has been studied. Data were obtained in integral reactor conditions and the rates of the products formation were computed by differentiation of experimental data yield versus contact time. Catalytic tests were performed over stoichiometric (Mo/Fe=1.5 at. ratio) and Mo rich (Mo/Fe=3 at. ratio) catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and sol-gel like techniques. The Mo/Fe atomic ratio of the catalysts seems to have a null effect on the methanol to formaldehyde kinetics what is coherent with the attribution of the active phase to the Fe2(MoO4)3, the main phase of the tested catalysts. A direct correlation between the CO formation and the Mo/Fe atomic ratio was not inferred mainly due to the different degrees of reduction of the tested catalysts (Fe2+/Fe3+), but the Mo/Fe ratio plays an important role on the consecutive oxidation of formaldehyde to CO thus controlling catalyst selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Methanol oxidation over iron molybdate catalysts. Main and side reactions kinetics
